intro: Sibbaldia phanerophlebia, commonly known as the Tibetan buttercup, is a flowering plant native to the high-altitude regions of the Himalayas and Central Asia. It belongs to the family Ranunculaceae, which includes many showy, often toxic plants. The plant is characterized by its yellow flowers, which are typically borne on stems that rise above the leaves. Its leaves are compound, with a distinctive palmate or pinnate structure, and it thrives in cold, arid environments. Sibbaldia phanerophlebia is adapted to harsh mountainous conditions, often growing at elevations above 3,000 meters.
